speechtext:
That the Standing Orders of the House of Commons be changed to indicate that only those votes which deal with government expenditure, grant or charge on the public revenue and sponsored by the Minister of Finance are considered to be votes of confidence in the government and no member other than the minister may move a motion which would increase public expenditures.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity today to debate this important issue, an issue that could have a tremendous impact on the way in which this House works.
There are several reasons why I put forward this motion and let me elaborate on them.
First of all, I am very interested in seeing a strengthening of the role of the private member in this House, which means private members on all sides of the House. By enhancing the role of the member, it enhances his or her ability to fight on behalf of his or her constituents, to represent those people. That is what I am doing today by putting forward this motion, speaking on behalf of the people of Macleod.
This motion would help ensure that the cabinet remains extremely responsive to private members on all sides of the House, responds to their needs and the representations they make on behalf of their constituents.
I also would like to remove the myth that is, I think, widely held, that the party Whip tells me as an MP how I should vote on every motion, every time I stand up to
record my vote. I stand up in this House to vote to represent the interests of the people of McLeod. There are times when I feel resentful of the implication that somehow I am told what to do, I am not party to the consensus that is arrived at, that we as a party put forward in motions and bills in this House. The other myth which has even less basis in truth is the myth that somehow the Prime Minister tells me how to vote on all issues.
We as a party work together. We come to a consensus. We fight it out. We have hammer and tongs discussions in caucus over issues that are important. We arrive at a decision and present that common front to the House. If I cannot agree I am fully free to stand up and vote against motions. I would like to have this motion accepted by the House to help eliminate those myths.
Another reason, and it comes directly to the next point, is that I would like to eliminate the risk of defeating a government over an issue that is really not a confidence motion. In an objective analysis, you stand back from it and say, should a government be defeated on this particular motion? In many cases there are issues that are before the House that should not cause the defeat of a government if they do not pass. They may well be objected to by members on the back bench on this side, or in the front, or in the back bench on the other side.
In a more general sense, I hope that this motion speaks to a sense of direction about the need for fundamental reform of central institutions in Canada. There is a general interest in the Canadian population to see a wide, fundamental institutional reform.
I had the privilege to serve on the Canada renewal committee and we heard this often from people who spoke to us. As we travelled across Canada people spoke of the need for Senate reform. I firmly believe in that. I believe we need to get on with that as soon as possible.
They spoke of the need for House of Commons reform. This is within the spirit of that need and I really hope that we can make some progress on this today. People spoke of making institutions like the House of Commons more responsive to the needs of the people of

April 6, 1992
Private Members' Business
Canada. This is one such measure that would help achieve that objective. The motion responds to that call and I believe it is absolutely the correct direction in which we need to go.
The motion is a significant issue which is of interest to all Canadians. It proposes fundamental changes to the rules of the House of Commons. Its purpose, in simple language, is to make all the votes in the House of Commons free votes except for those votes on money bills sponsored by the Minister of Finance.
As a result the government will not fall if it loses a vote on an issue that does not deal with money. That is the initial intent of this motion.
It will have a substantial change in the way in which this institution works. In effect, it will help open up the legislative process. It will ensure that some of the debates that now take place in private caucuses will take place more often here on the floor of the House of Commons.
All of us have had the experience of people telling us we did not speak for them on such and such an issue. People genuinely believe that if they do not see any evidence of their point of view being reflected in debate, they do not know that their point of view has even been taken into account. In most cases it has because we have had the debate in caucus.
For example, in the Alberta Conservative Progressive caucus, we take the issue to the national caucus and put forward our point of view. We then hammer away on issues that are important to us. None of us wins the day all the time. In a House of Commons of 295 members, nobody is ever going to win his or her point of view all the time. Even the Prime Minister does not win all the time.
It is important to get this debate out in the open a lot more to help strengthen the point of view, show the way in which legislation is developed, and the influence that we as individual members and Canadians as citizens have upon this institution.
I do not have to tell people here that Canadians in many walks of life have a lower opinion of this House than was the case 20 or 30 years ago. This is true of all
institutions in society. We have an opportunity to help rebuild the credibility of this institution because it is so important in society that the central institutions, the law-making bodies have the respect of Canadians and that Canadians feel that the House of Commons and the Senate genuinely reflect their objectives and their part of the country.
I have received a lot of comment over the last year since I introduced this motion in the House. Let me just quote from one. It is an editorial in the Nanton News entitled "Free Vote is Overdue". Let me just read a couple of paragraphs.
His motion, which is long-
"His" is referring to the member of Parliament for Macleod.
His motion, which is long overdue, would allow MPs to vote on issues according to their own judgment, and not necessarily follow the party line.
As it stands now, if a motion by a cabinet minister is defeated, that is shown as a non-confidence vote for the government and an election must be called. There's little wonder government members follow the party line, when their very jobs could be in jeopardy.
The motion introduced by Hughes is exactly the kind of down to earth, grass roots thinking his constituents expect from him. He's right when he says people are calling for a more visible and effective voice in the nation's capital.
It remains to be seen whether Hughes' Tbiy teammates will be quick to adopt his motion. It was however, one of the promises made in the last Speech from the Throne.
It also remains to be seen whether MPs will vote independently, even if the legislation allowing them to do so is in place. You'll have to excuse Canadians if they adopt a wait-and-see attitude on the actions of politicians who have let them down numerous times in recent years.
This editorial, while endorsing the general concept that I have put forward, also raises some of the other fundamental issues which I think we have to deal with in this House. I look forward to that debate.
We have an opportunity to make an historic change. It is a chance to renew the faith of a sceptical Canadian public. The motion is all about making individual members of Parliament more effective in the job they do for their constituents and I cannot think of a better place to do this than in Private Members' Business. Canadians want and deserve these changes and I think this is our opportunity to respond.
April 6, 1992

Private Members' Business
I presume that some of our colleagues opposite may want to point out some detail of this motion which may be flawed in wording or with which they might not agree and use that as a reason to disagree with this motion. One of our colleagues opposite says "never" and I hope that is the case.
In anticipation of that I would like to propose an amendment which would go even further and clarify the intent of this motion. I have heard from lots of Canadians in addition to the editor of the Nanton News and I have had the opportunity to respond to some of those very legitimate criticisms.
I seek permission to introduce an amendment to my motion which would read as follows:
That the motion be amended by striking out all the words after the
phrase "indicate that" so that the motion now reads:
That the Standing Orders of the House of Commons be changed to
indicate that all votes, except for those that deal explicitly with the
matter of confidence in the government be considered as free votes.
If I may clarify that, I think this amendment should be accepted because it seeks to spell out when a vote is a free vote or when it is a confidence vote and when it is not. The original motion spelled out specific votes. This amendment does the same, but in a more clear manner and in a way which responds to criticisms I have heard from Canadians.
I ask for the support of the House in order to put that amendment forward.

Mr. Speaker, this is what we would call imaginative rule making.

I do not think the Chair could say that Christmas Day is June 25. We all know that is impossible. Private Members' Business

This is my own view and I would like you to quote for me chapter and verse of which book gives you that authority to ask for unanimous consent.

Mr. Speaker, I just want to intervene for a few moments to contrast the arguments of my hon. friend who has a great deal of experience with the rules and procedures of this House.
I think you are perfectly in order, Mr. Speaker, to ask if something can be done by unanimous consent, because unanimous consent allows the House to supersede its own rules and procedures. Mr. Speaker, I thank you and distinguished, experienced colleagues opposite and on this side for their advice in dealing with this question.
I believe that there may well be an interest by other members in this House in putting forward the motion to amend which I attempted to do myself. I would certainly hope that is the case because it is important. There is a difference between simply trying to define what question should be a question of confidence and what question is not a question of confidence in this House.
It is not something that is easily defined. Perhaps the best way to define it is by simply saying any motion which essentially defines itself as a motion of confidence. That way members opposite from all of the parties not in the government could put forward a motion and define it as a motion of confidence. They could put forward their motions. The government could choose to put forward its motions indicating when it is a question of confidence and when it is not.
Perhaps that helps us get away from trying to define a long list of times or specific types of motions which are questions of confidence and which are not questions of confidence. The amendment which I sought to put forward today seeks to do that.
I would at this point accept the advice of my hon. colleague from Peace River and seek the unanimous consent of the House in order to have this motion referred to the committee which the hon. member for Peace River chairs, the House management committee.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise to participate in the debate on this motion today, flawed as it is. I recognize the hon. member has tried to make changes in it. I think he became aware of the concerns that I had about the motion when the motion came before the subcommittee of the House management committee to decide whether or not the motion should be made a votable one.
I indicated that it was completely unacceptable in its present form because it in effect gave the government the power to decide what items were to be considered votes of confidence, which in some ways it has already. But at least under our current practice there is some constitutional convention that certain votes in this House be regarded as matters of confidence.
I would not want to presume to give an exhaustive list to the House on this important issue, but certainly the list would include votes on specific motions of non-confidence which the member appears to have omitted from his motion which I think are clearly matters of confidence. Those arise generally during the debate on the budget and during the debate on the Address in Reply to the Speech from the Throne.
In addition, I submit that a defeat on a major supply bill, such as an interim supply bill or the final supply bill, would constitute a failure of confidence in the government and would require the resignation of the government or possibly a dissolution of Parliament.
April 6, 1992

Private Members' Business
In addition to that list, I think a defeat on a major government bill that had been the basis of an election campaign and which the government put forward as one of its major planks would constitute a serious lack of confidence in the government. I would cite as an example of that a defeat on the free trade bill. Similarly, a defeat on a major budget bill might also constitute a question of confidence, but it would depend on whether the bill was rejected outright or whether there was some other difficulty with it.
Those are areas where I submit the government has an obligation at least to look at the vote as one of confidence. The idea that we should set up a set of rules in the House dealing with the issue is one that I am not in agreement with.
The other side of the coin that I think is important is that the government itself may consider certain matters to be votes of confidence and may choose to resign if it loses them. I think that the option for a government to make that kind of decision is one that needs to be open, should the government elect to use its position to say a defeat on this matter will result in an election or in resignation.
I think the government must always have that right, to be exercised at any time. If the rules of the House say that the government cannot do it in effect by listing those things which are matters of confidence, I think we have done a disservice to our system. The parliamentary system works by convention. Everything is not written. There are certain rules that are unwritten and perhaps their imprecision is helpful. We have some cases where the rules are bent one way. Sometimes they are bent another.
I think the advantage of our system is there is this flexibility because the matters are not put down in writing. Having said that, perhaps the intent of the hon. member was to lessen the strictures that the government places on him, as one of the government's backbenchers, to vote with the government. I can understand his anxiety to get away from having to vote with this particular government at any time. If that is his intention, I applaud it and I would invite him simply to come over to this side of the House and vote against it at every opportunity. He might feel more comfortable, but that is unnecessary to this debate.
What he is trying to do is free up votes in the House of Commons, and I commend him for that effort. It is something that is worth while. The question of freeing up votes is an interesting one because the debate is carried on in two planes. We have those who say we must have more free votes in the House. They urge members to break ranks with the party at every opportunity and vote in accordance with their own conviction or the view of their constituents, depending whether the two coincide. Presumably, it is to represent their constituents better, either by voting in accordance with their own view or that of their constituents. That is one argument.
The second plane or argument is that you free up votes by removing confidence votes from the House, by having fewer of those. Once that is done, particularly members supporting the government would feel freer in then-votes because they would know that their vote would not bring the government down. It would not result in an immediate election. They would then know that they can express their disapproval of government policy by voting with the opposition and indicating they are opposed to the bill the government is proceeding with.
Frankly, it is the second argument that should be pursued. That is really the hon. member's intention, I think, in his wording. In my view, declaring free votes in this House will not help our political system. What we need to do is say that there will be fewer votes of confidence in this House. When voting on a bill like plant breeders' rights or the bill dealing with the transportation of hazardous substances, which we debated on Friday, or the bill we will be debating later today, a loss on one of those bills would not constitute a loss of confidence in the government. To my mind that would make sense. I am not sure there would be many who would argue that a loss on one of those bills would, in fact, constitute a loss of confidence in the government.
I have no doubt that if the government lost one of those bills in this House, the government would then introduce a motion of confidence and have it passed. The time to make that change is at the next election campaign when the governing party can announce in the next election that it will not regard votes on minor bills as matters of confidence. If that happens, it will free up votes in this House, which I think is a laudable aim.
April 6, 1992

I do not think we can free up votes in this House simply by saying that party strictures are abandoned. Members are going to vote with their party on most occasions because parties represent a coalition of interests. Members band together in parties because they believe they can be more effective working together than working apart. If each member of this House made his or her own decision on every issue, we would have real difficulty in coming to decisions in this place because members would be voting all over the map. There would be an unwillingness to compromise, to make a decision that is in the best interests of everyone.
The advantage that the party system provides to the Canadian voter and is often forgotten is that it forces members to compromise. They get together and say: "1 will vote for your bill on this if you will vote for my bill on that". It is that kind of compromise that is made behind the scenes and in party caucus in many cases that affects the outcome of votes in this House, gets bills through and it makes the country work. It does work.
If we take away all those strictures and say it is a free for all, we will find that members are ganging up in coalitions that are out to break or stop the passage of certain bills instead of trying to do something constructive.
The party disciplinary system has its place. We need it. We can do with more free votes. I submit that the way to get it is to reduce the number of votes that are considered to be ones of confidence in the government.
For the benefit of the House, the Standing Committee on House Management has been dealing with this issue. There have been discussions. There has been an excellent document prepared by my good friend Professor Franks of Queen's University on this very issue, prepared for the government and released to the members of the committee. The committee is continuing its study. The subcommittee on parliamentary reform is drafting a report at this time, part of which will include some statement concerning free votes in the House of Commons and the confidence convention as it applies in this House. I am sure that at some point a document will
Private Members' Business
come forward from the committee for discussion in this place.
While I welcome the hon. member's motion, I suggest that the wording of it is very seriously flawed. I appreciate the opportunity to have a brief discussion about it in the House. I believe it will come back. I urge the hon. member to continue his efforts and perhaps file a new motion later which may get drawn for debate as this one has and we can have yet another run at the issue.

Mr. Speaker, I too want to participate in this debate. The unamended motion before us deals with two elements. The first is that only those votes which deal with government expenditure and proposed by the Minister of Finance would be excluded. Second, no member other than a minister may move a motion which would increase public expenditures.
The motion basically is redundant as far as the first part because the Standing Orders have been changed as a result of the McGrath report to allow a different view of confidence motions. We have argued in this House on a number of occasions, particularly as they relate to opposition days, more technically known as supply days, that governments need not consider the motions as a matter of confidence. We have had some movement.
Members will recall the motion that my party submitted for an opposition day. It was amended, I believe, by the Official Opposition. It was with regard to GATT. The government decided that this was not a motion of confidence. It was providing an over-all direction to Parliament and specific direction to the Prime Minister. One wonders whether he has actually followed up on that. He was supposed to go out and meet with somebody. So the House has the power and the government has the power to make that determination now and have availed themselves.
On the other hand, when the Official Opposition moved a motion under its opposition day reaffirming support of medicare, the government chose to consider that a motion of confidence. One wonders whether the government in fact was a bit worried about what it has been doing to medicare by the changes in funding to the provinces, but that is for another debate on another day.

April 6, 1992
Private Members' Business
The government has taken both sides on this issue. I welcome the member's initiative to try and get some clarification. As he knows, the government itself, two days before he tabled his motion, promised to open up Parliament, to provide greater opportunity for private members to participate. Perhaps if he had not been in such a rush to follow the government's agenda, he might have been able to come up with the solution that he tried to introduce into this House a few moments ago.
There are two other elements in this. People have been using freely the phrases "free votes" and "confidence votes" as if they were one and the same. They are not. There is no restriction in the Standing Orders that prevents the Official Opposition, the New Democratic Party or the group of independents to have a collective vote. At any time at all my caucus can decide on any issue that members are free to vote as they wish with no guidance, no direction and no whipping from the caucus. In fact, we did that. When this House cast a vote on whether or not we should be in the gulf during the war last year, we asked the House to make it a free vote, that members be allowed to vote their conscience. The government said no. Even though the question of abortion was a free vote, it was a matter of conscience. Even though capital punishment was a free vote, it was a matter of conscience. To a lot of us war is a matter of conscience as well.
So we freed up our members. We made a caucus decision. We took a vote with a show of hands in our caucus as to whether or not it should be a free vote. We also debated the merits to provide some understanding of the members in terms of the issue. To say that a confidence vote is a free vote for everybody is not the case.
A confidence vote is a very specific tool that governments use to sustain themselves as government because if a government loses a confidence vote it loses the right to govern and it must go back to the people of Canada to get a new mandate or attempt to get a new mandate.
There are areas that this government has moved on that would suggest to many are not matters of confidence.
We have the coastal trading act which started 15 years ago coming through the system. It made it to the House just before the 1988 election was called. It got through the House and to the Senate. There were some disagreements between the parties but it was not part of the government's platform as pronounced in either the 1984 or 1988 campaigns. It was bringing a piece of legislation up to date.
Those types of matters could be looked at as issues not to be deemed confidence and not as part of the government's mandate or agenda where there could be come flexibility.
We have to recognize that part of the reason for the call for free votes in terms of the public view is really for change in the confidence vote system because people are angiy about the decisions the government has been making.
I found it interesting that the member's initial wording basically said that anything the Minister of Finance does we have to support.
Is the GST not from the Minister of Finance? Is that not the most hated tax this country has ever seen? Members on the government side like to suggest that if they had had the right to vote according to their conscience they would not have done it.
I would like government members to get up in this House and explain how they voted at their convention in Toronto a year ago. I assume, like our conventions, it is mandatory that they show up as a member of Parliament. I think it was 95 per cent of the delegates who endorsed the GST, after the fact, after this government had rammed it through.
Well you cannot have it both ways. You cannot be calling for free votes to try to appease your constituents who hate that tax. You cannot say you would have voted differently if you had had the right to a free vote.
They did not vote differently at the convention. The GST was in line with the philosophy and the approach of the Conservative Party and the Conservative government and the Conservative memberships. They do not deny that. They make no bones about it.
To suggest that things would be different if we had free votes is not the case. If there were free votes for everything but what the Minister of Finance does, the vast impact on Canadians is through the Minister of Finance, whether it is the GST, the income tax, the corporate tax-or should I say the lack of corporate tax-all of those things affect every Canadian on a daily basis.
April 6, 1992

It is the Minister of Finance who decides what money is going to go to health, to transportation, to external affairs. That is his budget. That sets the framework for the total operation of this country.
Having said that, the government of the day has the right because it has a mandate to govern the country. There is no question in my mind. So when we say we want to free up the government we have to recognize that it has certain responsibilities.
The government has the responsibility to manage the country properly. We may differ as to what properly means and we always differ on that because we all come to this House with different philosophies.
The government does have that right, but it also has the responsibility to ensure that what it does helps not hurts the responsibility and requirement that at some point it has to go back to the people.
The freest vote of all is the vote at election time. I sure wish we would have one soon.

Mr. Speaker, I certainly agree with the intent of this motion and wish to commend my friend for Macleod for presenting it.
It deals with two important issues, issues that all of us have talked about and have been approached by constituents about for many, many years. I regret we could not get unanimous approval of his earlier motion to refer the subject matter. I sincerely hope that we can reconsider that issue.
I listened to the member for Macleod during his presentation and I agree with the editorial support that he quoted. People are calling for a more open, more visible system of government. This is an issue that is of concern to many, many Canadians.
Like the member for Macleod, I was elected and I came here to represent my constituents. Their interests come first. Many of those people have the impression, gathered from reports of confidence votes, that we are nothing but a group of trained seals in this place. We do not have the opportunity to really speak out and fully represent them.
Private Members' Business
Every weekend when I go home, constituents express frustration with the debates and the votes they see in this place. Most of these people have a very strong feeling about Canada. They have a strong feeling about the issues that are in front of us. They want to express themselves and they want to participate. They want to see their representatives in the House of Commons participating freely.
The member for Macleod has identified two issues that Canadians do have strong feelings about and two issues that many Canadians do not fully understand. They are issues that have generated and will continue to generate much thought and discussion. Yet to the public, it seems that we are limited to this very short debate. speechtext:
There is one motion in amendment at report stage to Bill C-31, an act to amend the Extradition Act.

The motion submitted by the hon. member for Port Moody-Coquitlam will be debated and voted on.

Motion No. 1
That Bill C-31 be amended in Clause 4
(a) by striking out lines 42 to 45 on page 5 and substituting the following therefor:
"23. (1) Subject to section (2), a fugitive shall not be surrendered
(a)	until after the expiration of thirty days after an order of surrender in respect of the fugitive is made by the Minister of Justice under section 25; or"
(b)	by striking out line 2 on page 6 and substituting the following
therefor
"the court and the expiration of any period of time in which a further appeal or application for leave to appeal to another court may be filed.
(2) A fugitive may inform the Minister, in writing, that the fugitive does not propose to commence an appeal or proceedings for a judicial review in respect of any matter arising under this Act, and where the Minister is so informed, the fugitive may be surrendered forthwith."
He said: Let me just bring the House up to date as to where we are on this bill. This is the extradition bill.
Extradition is when someone commits an offence in another country, comes to Canada, is arrested in Canada, and then the other country applies to Canada to extradite that person.
A good example was the Charles Ng case. My friend has just said it is a bad example and that is part of the reason we have the bill. Mr. Ng was alleged to have committed a number of murders in California. He came to Canada and was arrested here, luckily, over an incident. It was actually a shoplifting theft incident in Calgary, I believe. He then went to a Canadian jail and awaited extradition.
Our extradition laws have been in need of revamping. I think we would all agree, every side of the House would agree with that. Certainly we got a thorough airing of the law in terms of the number of appeals that Mr. Ng went through. Most of us thought it was too long; some people would cut it very short. A number of us felt in the House that what we have to do is get a balance to get a fair procedure.
I underline this to the members of the House, the reason the Ng case went on so long was that Ng challenged through his lawyers the principle of whether Canada could extradite or send someone back to a country that had the death penalty for murder when we do not have the death penalty here. The Supreme Court decided that in fact Canada could send people back to a country that had the death penalty.
The minister does not have to do that. Just recently the Minister of Justice in extraditing someone to Florida said: "I will extradite the person to Florida as long as you give me an undertaking that the death penalty will not be asked for'. There is some fairly wide discretion.
April 6, 1992

One of the problems, as I have outlined before, is in an extradition case like Charles Ng there seems to be almost an abuse-not an abuse because you are entitled to an appeal-with appeal, after appeal, after appeal. There was delay. On the other hand, a decade ago there was the case of Leonard Pelletier, an Indian activist, an aboriginal leader in the United States, who history seems to say was extradited on fabricated evidence, affidavits. That is a blot on the Canadian justice system. Mr. Pelletier is still in jail in the United States.
We do not want that to happen. We have to find a fair way. All members of the justice committee, and I am looking at my friend from Peterborough, my friend from Cape Breton-The Sydneys and so on, tried to find some system that would be fair and have fair procedural matters but would not involve too long a delay.
What does my amendment do? My amendment catches a matter that I think is a fault in the bill. What happens is that when the appeals are exhausted, the minister decides under section 25, because it is a political decision at that point, a decision of state, to agree to the extradition as has been ordered by the Canadian courts, after all appeals have been exhausted. There is a tendency, and we saw it in a recent case, of suddenly the person is gone right out of the country right away. There was not even a chance for the lawyer to even meet with his client. That is pretty tacky, it seems to me, and not within the principles of justice that we should have in Canada.
My amendment simply gives a short period in which there can be a consideration of further appeals or a consideration of getting things in order before the person is actually extradited to the country that is seeking the extradition. It seems to me that is fair and just. That is not a long delay.
Not only that, I am following what the Canadian Bar Association said. I draw your attention, Mr. Speaker, to the Canadian Bar Association regarding the date of surrender. I quote their brief to the legislative committee on this bill: "A fugitive should not be surrendered to a foreign state until he or she has had an opportunity to exhaust all rights of appeal provided under the Extradition Act".
I am just checking my notes of what the bar said: "A fugitive should not be surrendered to a foreign state
Government Orders
until he or she has an opportunity to exhaust all rights of appeal provided under the Extradition Act. Allowing the fugitive an opportunity to exhaust such rights requires that he or she have a reasonable period of time following any decision to determine whether or not to file an appeal or to apply for judicial review. Paragraph 23(a) of the act, as proposed in Bill C-31, does not provide the fugitive with a reasonable period of time following a decision by the minister under subsection 25(1). Further, proposed paragraph 23(b) does not allow the fugitive a reasonable period of time following a decision by a court of appeal to bring an application for leave to appeal to the Supreme Court of Canada".
The recommendation that is set out is recommendation 12 of the Canadian Bar Association. I basically followed that in the drafting of my amendment which was read to the House.
We heard in the committee from Donald MacLeod, the lawyer for Charles Ng. If I might say parenthetically, I was very impressed with Mr. MacLeod. John Diefen-baker once said this: It is tough for a lawyer to take a pretty unpopular case. This was an unpopular case. MacLeod in my view handled it well. He handled himself very well in front of our committee. I think all members felt that way. Mr. MacLeod said before our committee, and I quote:
If surrender is effective before a Notice of Appeal is actually filed, access to the appeals process contemplated by the bill can be completely frustrated.
I draw the member's attention to what Mr. MacLeod said at page 13 of his brief. I quote:
As currently drafted, the bill makes no provision for automatic stays of execution during all appeal periods. If surrender is affected before Notice of Appeal is actually filed, access to the appeals contemplated by the bill can be completely frustrated.
I would suggest automatic stays such as those contemplated by former provisions of the Criminal Code for death penalty cases as means of guaranteeing access to appeal process, section 604 and section 607(3) of the Criminal Code as they stood in 1975.
There is a precedent.
I asked the question of some departmental officials who were with the parliamentary secretary, whom I welcome. I see him in the House, the member for Niagara Falls. The departmental officials rejected my amendment. They said that the amendment would mean cases like that of Mr. Obomsawin, who, it is reported,

April 6, 1992
Government Orders
wanted to be extradited immediately. They said the minister's hands would be tied.
That is not true. In other words, this is someone who did not want an appeal, "Just get me extradited". You will see from my amendment, clause 2, I say:
A fugitive may inform the Minister, in writing, that the fugitive does
not propose to commence an appeal or proceedings for a judicial
review in respect of any matter arising under this Act, and where the
Minister is so informed, the fugitive may be surrendered forthwith.
That takes care of that argument.
The second argument the department put up was that the amendment would mean a stay of execution of up to 120 days should the Supreme Court be in summer recess. They are technically right. July and August are excluded from the computation of the 30-day and 60-day limits normally applied to appeals, if you look at the Supreme Court Act and the Federal Court Act. How many cases will this actually affect? We are just talking of that period of the summer which affects everything in our judicial system anyway. Do we toss out the principle of fair and even-handed application of justice, the very principle of our right to appeal that the legislation recognizes, simply because the court has gone fishing for the summer?
There could be a short delay in some cases in the summer. That is a pretty weak argument, it seems to me, for arguing against my motion.
In the couple of minutes remaining, I would just draw the House's attention to the evidence of David Givens, a trial lawyer from Vancouver, who has done a lot of extradition cases, including the Reyat Interjit Singh case involving the bombing of the Indian airliner. Mr. Givens said that-

I would suggest you look in the Givens' statement. Look at some of the evidence in other cases, the difficulty lawyers have contacting their client, arranging
matters, talking further about appeals and so on. This amendment is not asking much. It is simply asking that after all appeals are exhausted and the minister is about to grant the extradition that there be a short period, as I say in my bill, of up to 30 days, to give counsel time to meet with his or her client, to look at the matter, to decide where they are going from there.
That is not unreasonable. As I said to the House, we in the NDP will support the extradition bill. I suggest the government might consider supporting this amendment.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to speak on this amendment. I have a concern, and I am hoping that the hon. parliamentary secretary can address it. Like the member for Port Moody-Coquitlam, I have a concern on this. It is a fundamental concern.
My concern is not that the lawyer have a chance to speak with his client after all the rights of appeal have elapsed, to say goodbye or whatever he wants to do, take him to the World Court or whatever. We have here in this process a right of appeal. My concern is that upon having a judicial review of the order of extradition, the government has the power to whisk the person who is the subject of the extradition order out of the country before that person has the right to file a right of appeal.
I was not there to listen to the Canadian Bar Association's suggested amendment, but from reading this, this would seem to me to be their concern: that you have the hearing, the hearing is over and immediately upon the finish of the hearing, the person is whisked on to a plane and taken out of the country before that person has a chance to file an appeal.
That would seem to be a denial of the person's fundamental right under this act and under the fundamental right of justice actually. If, in fact, it is a question merely of the person being able to be taken out of the country immediately after the finish of the hearing of the appeal, I have no problem with that.
I feel that if there is a right of appeal, the person who is the subject of this hearing should be given time to speak with his or her lawyer about filing that appeal. To me, this is not clear. I would hope that the parliamentary secretary could give me some information and clarify this for me.

speakeroldname: Mr. Rob Nicholson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to say a few words at the report stage of BUI C-31, the extradition bUl. I hope to have the opportunity as well tomorrow when this comes up for third reading stage.
There are quite a few defects at the present time. Whatever else we can say about the extradition law in this country, I think we can say three things for sure. We can say that the law is enormously complex as it stands now. It results in long delays, and it requires a great deal of costly court time. It has those three defects, all of which I think most Canadians would agree should be remedied.
I suggest that the extradition bill that is presently before Parliament goes to those three problems that I find. The present legislation as it now stands gives an opportunity for an individual who is fighting extradition to get as many as three times in sequence the opportunity to have his or her case reviewed by the Supreme Court of Canada; three times in sequence.
Tell me what other forum or what other law in Canada would provide that kind of opportunity for an individual. One of the problems, and perhaps the major problem with the extradition law in this country as it is now, is that it provides that individual who has come here far more remedies than are available to a person charged with a criminal offence under Canadian law. You get far more remedies, far more kicks at the can if you have come from elsewhere to Canada to try to pursue your rights than if you are a Canadian citizen charged with an offence in this country.
As I say, you cannot give me another case where you or anyone would have a case, a problem or a charge that could be reviewed three times in sequence by the Supreme Court of Canada. You cannot come up with any examples because it only exists in the extradition law.
That is why the government, rightly so, has come forward with the changes. With respect to the motion presented by the hon. member for Port Moody-Coquitlam, I would suggest that the effect of the amendment would be to prevent the surrender of a fugitive to a foreign state until either the expiration of 30 days after the Minister of Justice makes a surrender order under section 25 or the expiration of any appeal periods or any
Government Orders
periods in which to make an application for leave to appeal, whichever time is later.
Presumably the reason for the suggested amendment is to prohibit the surrender until after the relevant appeal periods have expired in their entirety, whether or not the fugitive has actually filed an appeal or an application for leave to appeal.
The amendments contained in Bill C-31, include a statutory bar to surrender where an appeal is actually pending. In other words, a fugitive could not be surrendered where a notice of appeal has been filed on behalf of that fugitive according to the provisions of Bill C-31. These provisions do not contain a prohibition on surrender during the periods in which an appeal or leave to appeal may be initiated, if an appeal has not actually been taken.
The reason that a prohibition on surrender of the nature contemplated by the hon. member's amendment is not included in Bill C-31 is that it increases, in our opinion, the likelihood of delay. Bill C-31, on the other hand, encourages appeals on behalf of the fugitive to be initiated promptly. This is consistent with the general aim of the bill which I indicated earlier, which is to reduce delays in the handling of extradition cases in this country.
A legislative prohibition on surrender within the statutory appeal periods, where no appeal has been filed as proposed by the hon. member, has the potential to be abused by fugitives who are seeking a means to stall a likely surrender.
For example, in the case of an appeal to the Supreme Court of Canada, this amendment could result in a delay of up to four months before an appeal is filed where the summer recess of the court is calculated as part of the period within which to apply for leave to appeal. Otherwise the amount of time permitted to appeal to the Supreme Court under the Supreme Court of Canada Act is 60 days.
Out of concern over opening up the possibility of inordinate delay, the government is unable to support the amendment of the hon. member for Port Moody- Coquitlam. Instead the government intends to re-examine the issue of forestalling surrender of a fugitive during appeal periods.

April 6, 1992
Government Orders
A comprehensive review of all aspects of Canadian legislation in this area is taking place and certainly members of the government hope to introduce further changes to this area of the law later this year. In the meantime, I would suggest to hon. members, because of the possibility of delay, because of the possibility of abuse which goes contrary to the stated intentions of this bill, they turn down the suggested amendment by the hon. member.

Mr. Speaker, just on a small point.
My concern is with the fundamental right of justice. I think this is basically a very good bill. Our party has no problem with the bill over all. It is a step in the right direction.
As the hon. parliamentary secretary has said, there were far too many appeal processes that were not really necessary. But this bill, through the ability of the country to whom the person is sought to be extradited, has a chance to make application and the person who is the point of the extradition has the chance to appeal. I think it looks after these areas.
My concern, and I have stated it to the parliamentary secretary, is that while it gives the right of appeal to the person the government is seeking to extradite and says this person cannot be deported, turn this person over to the other country while this appeal is pending. The problem is, once the hearing is finished the government has the right to whisk this person out of the country before this person has an opportunity to speak to his or her lawyer on the question. There would be no way to file an appeal, therefore, the appeal cannot be pending if it is not filed. If the right of appeal is there why is the person being arbitrarily denied that right? That is my only concern and I think it is a valid one in the motion proposed by the member for Port Moody-Coquitlam.

I am always pleased to speak a second time, Mr. Speaker. I am very enthusiastic about this bill.
I have heard the concerns of the hon. member. I can indicate to him that in our review of the bill in this area we will have a look at that to make sure we have struck a balance between the government's and the Canadian people's justified concern in seeing that these matters are held in an expeditious manner and are dealt with in a fair manner and the concerns expressed by the hon. member on behalf of an individual who is the subject of an order sending him back to his or her country of origin.
We will be having a look at it, but I think the present law has erred on the side of providing for too much delay, too much review and too much stalling. I think this is one of the reasons why Canadians have come forward and said to us that we must do something about extradition in this country because that kind of legislation is not working.
The hon. member says: "We have erred on the other side. Now we are trying to rush these people out of there". I can say to him that during the review of the bill, the witnesses who came forward and my interpretation of the bill, I think it does strike the balance. It is in conformity with the tenets of fairness that we expect within Canadian laws and within the Canadian judicial system.
I do not think it goes too far the other way in trying to hurry these individuals. That is certainly not the intention of the bill. It is that everyone should be dealt with in a fair but expeditious manner that takes into consideration our collective rights as Canadians to have a system that works and is not open to abuse.

Mr. Speaker, I will not take much time because I see that all three parties are supporting this bill.
I want to emphasize to the House how many representations I had from my constituents in Parkdale-High Park about this extradition bill. Their biggest concern is that the criminals we are harbouring in Canada have more rights than the victims.

He said: This bill in front of us today does two or three significant things.
Part of the bill deals with the extension and improvement of equalization payments for seven provinces throughout the country. We have no quarrel with that part of the bill, nor have we moved any amendments with respect to it.
A second part of the bill provides a guarantee of personal income tax revenues to provinces, and that
guarantee is extended for two years in the bill. We feel it is important that this bill have the effect of increasing the sense of urgency to deal with the whole set of problems associated with transfer payments in this country, as the federal government has been off-loading many of its costs onto the provinces by reducing the expected amount of transfer payments for the provinces.
We have moved an amendment which reduces the extension of this guarantee from two years to one year. Within this one year period, it should be possible to deal with some of the serious problems which exist with respect to other transfer payments besides the equalization system.
The third thing this bill does, which is what this set of amendments deals with, is make it possible for provinces to enter into arrangements with the federal government to effectively establish harmonization of sales tax regimes so the goods and services tax, which we so profoundly object to, can be harmonized with provincial sales tax regimes.
We have seen and heard from every manner of small business across this country. Whether this small business happens to be in the service sector, in manufacturing, the comer grocery store, or the diaper service that services your child, we have heard nothing but horror stories about the way the goods and services tax has imposed a massively increased administrative burden on these small businesses.
I have sat and talked with small business people in my constituency who have told me they have to take as much time now to deal with the administration of this tax as they do to promote their businesses. I can tell you about specific cases.
The Great Canadian Trading Company, for instance, is an important business employing people and selling Canadian items to tourists coming from the United States in the Windsor area. The owner of this business has told me she has to spend over half her time administering this goods and services tax. It is not because she is an uneducated person. It is because her business is a particularly complicated business. It is not large enough to justify hiring a specialist to look after the administrative problems of the goods and services tax. Her small enterprise purchases Canadian craft goods
April 6, 1992

from over 800 different suppliers from across the country.
That kind of business finds itself absolutely crippled by the goods and services tax. The government has suggested to us that we can somehow solve some of these administrative problems by creating one grand tax covering both provincial and federal revenues. It would be a super goods and services tax which would somehow make things easier for small businesses. It will not. It will make things more difficult for small businesses across this country. What is already a problem for firms, such as the one I referred to in my comments, will become an even bigger problem.
We have moved these amendments because we think they should be taken out of this piece of legislation. We think there should be nothing in this piece of legislation that gives any stamp of approval to the goods and services tax. As far as we are concerned, this tax should be eliminated from the arsenal of tax measures in this country.
If we get the chance to form the government after the next election it will be eliminated, and it will be eliminated because it is a bad tax. It establishes an inequality between small businesses in Canada and those in the United States, which is so grossly unfair that those small businesses on our side of the border simply cannot compete effectively.
We must give those small businesses in Canada a fighting chance to compete effectively, not against countries in Europe which have value-added taxes, but against companies in the United States where they do not. When we visited Washington a few months ago we were told they have no chance of putting a value-added tax into effect. To establish fairness of competition for our small businesses here in this country facing small businesses right across the border in the U.S., we must see to it no stamp of approval whatsoever is given to the GST. That is why I urge people in this House to vote for these amendments. They will have the effect of stopping this government's continuing efforts to legitimize a bad tax which has increased the recession, put more people out of work in Canada, and made life much, much more difficult for small business people right across this country.

I hope these sets of amendments, which I have moved with respect to this legislation, will be accepted for that reason.

speechtext:
I appreciate the intervention of the hon. member but I think I will carry on.
Honourable members will be aware that the proposed amendments to the revenue guarantee do not directly affect the main purpose of the proposed legislation before us, the renewal enhancement of the equalization program. However, just because this House is aware of this distinction, it does not mean the provinces or the public in general will seize this subtlety. Therefore, it is important all of this legislation apply for a period of two years.
There are good reasons for having chosen to renew the equalization program for two years. Renewal at the traditional five-year period would have given every appearance of a lessened federal commitment to the current review of all three major transfer programs.

Government Orders
Such a message would not reflect our intentions, so we did not want to send it.
We considered the other extreme of reviewing the equalization program for a single year, but this would have turned up the heat for the transfer review process and left the seven equalization-receiving provinces without the transfer revenue certainty they need for reasonable planning horizons.
After more than 20 months of consultations with the provinces, we settled on a two-year renewal period. We believe it offers the best balance between the need for impetus and flexibility in the review process, and revenue certainty for the provinces.

I would now like to refer to tax administration and turn to the proposed deletion of clauses related to tax administration amendments.
The clause in question set out a legal framework for amendment agreements between the provinces and the federal government, providing for the administration and enforcement of a federal tax by a province, or the administration of a provincial tax by the federal government.
Such agreements improve the over-all efficiency of the Canadian tax system and thereby contribute to a better tax system. The provisions of the bill also simplify the payment of taxes for individuals in cases where an agreement has been entered into.
The clauses in question provide for simplification of payments in taxes and refunds in cases where a province is administering a federal tax. In such cases, the bill allows the taxpayer to validly pay the province the federal tax that the province is administering.
The province will also be able to pay tax refunds to an individual on behalf of the federal government. In this way, it will be simpler for a taxpayer to pay and to receive refunds of a federal tax that is administered by a province. Under these clauses, the same is true of
provincial taxes that are administered by the federal government.
The clauses in question also provide for simplified remittance to the federal government of taxes collected by a province on behalf of the federal government. In such cases, the clauses state that the province may deduct from the taxes so collected the amount that it has paid to persons on behalf of the federal government.
The remittance of provincial taxes collected by the federal government will also be simplified under these clauses. I could go on, but I think the House gets the point. We are talking about making tax administration and enforcement more efficient and hence less expensive.
Canadians have made it abundantly clear that they expect their governments to do everything they can to improve efficiency and cost effectiveness. I say to the House that we should retain the clauses that are proposed for deletion.
